clusters.title: Chief executive of Care Quality Commission steps down over inquiry into NHS trust
clusters.neutral_headline: Chief executive of Care Quality Commission steps down over inquiry into NHS trust: Sir Julian Hartley says his role at CQC is ‘incompatible’ with investigation into maternity failings at Leeds trust he led for 10 yearsThe chief executive of the Care Quality Commission has quit after the announcement of an independent inquiry into maternity failings at an NHS trust he led for a decade.Sir Julian Hartley said staying in his current role was “incompatible” with the investigation into Leeds teaching hospitals NHS trust (LTH) which he led for 10 years until 2023, and raised concerns it could “undermine trust and confidence in the regulator”. Continue reading

clusters.title: One in 12 secondary pupils put in isolation rooms at least once a week, study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: School Isolation Rooms Used Frequently, Study Finds

items.title: One in 12 secondary pupils put in isolation rooms at least once a week, study finds
items.standfirst: Children with special educational needs more than twice as likely to be put in isolation, say Manchester researchers‘Publicly humiliated’: parents describe difficulty of children’s isolation at schoolOne in 12 secondary pupils report being put into school isolation rooms at least once a week where they often spend in excess of eight hours, missing more than a full day of lessons, according to research.Children with special educational needs were more than twice as likely to be placed in isolation, otherwise known as internal exclusion, while students from low-income backgrounds were also disproportionately affected. Continue reading...
items.content: Children with special educational needs more than twice as likely to be put in isolation, say Manchester researchers‘Publicly humiliated’: parents describe difficulty of children’s isolation at schoolOne in 12 secondary pupils report being put into school isolation rooms at least once a week where they often spend in excess of eight hours, missing more than a full day of lessons, according to research.Children with special educational needs were more than twice as likely to be placed in isolation, otherwise known as internal exclusion, while students from low-income backgrounds were also disproportionately affected. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A study reveals one in twelve secondary pupils are isolated weekly in schools.
Children with special educational needs are more than twice as likely to be isolated.
Isolation often involves students missing over a full day of lessons.
Low-income students are also disproportionately affected by school isolation.
Parents describe the difficulty of children's isolation at school.

clusters.title: ‘The pressure to get your old body back is immense’: the new mothers driven to weight-loss jabs
clusters.neutral_headline: Mothers and Weight-Loss Jabs: Pressure to Regain Body

items.title: ‘The pressure to get your old body back is immense’: the new mothers driven to weight-loss jabs
items.standfirst: The NHS warns against using GLP-1s while breastfeeding – for the baby’s sake as well as the mother’s. But how much does that count when they’re so readily available and there’s so much pressure to ‘bounce back’?Lydia* first started thinking about weight-loss drugs during pregnancy. “Everyone was talking about them and the advertisements were everywhere,” she says, as her baby son naps upstairs. “I remember thinking: ‘That’s how I’ll lose weight for my wedding next year.’”When Lydia explains that most of her life before pregnancy was spent in a welter of yo-yo dieting and body dissatisfaction, I say to her that I think most of us can relate. Her pregnancy, however, brought a level of body acceptance and contentment that the 33-year-old from Wales had never had before. Continue reading...
items.content: The NHS warns against using GLP-1s while breastfeeding – for the baby’s sake as well as the mother’s. But how much does that count when they’re so readily available and there’s so much pressure to ‘bounce back’?Lydia* first started thinking about weight-loss drugs during pregnancy. “Everyone was talking about them and the advertisements were everywhere,” she says, as her baby son naps upstairs. “I remember thinking: ‘That’s how I’ll lose weight for my wedding next year.’”When Lydia explains that most of her life before pregnancy was spent in a welter of yo-yo dieting and body dissatisfaction, I say to her that I think most of us can relate. Her pregnancy, however, brought a level of body acceptance and contentment that the 33-year-old from Wales had never had before. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The NHS warns against using GLP-1s while breastfeeding for the baby's sake.
Advertisements for weight-loss drugs are prevalent, influencing new mothers.
Some mothers consider weight-loss drugs to lose weight for events.
Pregnancy brought a level of body acceptance for some women.
Many women experience body dissatisfaction and yo-yo dieting.

clusters.title: NHS health checks in England to have questions on menopause for first time
clusters.neutral_headline: NHS Health Checks to Include Menopause Questions

items.title: NHS health checks in England to have questions on menopause for first time
items.standfirst: Experts welcome the addition but urge the health service to improve awareness of checks in the first placeNHS health checks are to include questions about the menopause for the first time, ministers have announced, with millions of women in England expected to benefit.Adults aged from 40 to 74 who do not have a pre-existing long-term health condition are eligible for an NHS health check every five years. The checks are intended to identify those at higher risk of heart and kidney disease, type 2 diabetes, dementia and stroke. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts welcome the addition but urge the health service to improve awareness of checks in the first placeNHS health checks are to include questions about the menopause for the first time, ministers have announced, with millions of women in England expected to benefit.Adults aged from 40 to 74 who do not have a pre-existing long-term health condition are eligible for an NHS health check every five years. The checks are intended to identify those at higher risk of heart and kidney disease, type 2 diabetes, dementia and stroke. Continue reading...

ai_summary: NHS health checks in England will include questions about menopause.
Millions of women in England are expected to benefit from the change.
Adults aged 40 to 74 without pre-existing conditions are eligible.
Checks aim to identify those at risk of various health issues.
Experts welcome the addition but urge improved awareness of checks.

clusters.title: Weight-loss drug cuts heart attack risk regardless of kilograms shed, study finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Weight-Loss Drug Reduces Heart Attack Risk

items.title: Weight-loss drug cuts heart attack risk regardless of kilograms shed, study finds
items.standfirst: Semaglutide study suggests such drugs could have wider benefits, though researchers find shrinking waistlines linked to better heart outcomesThe weight-loss drug semaglutide cuts the risk of heart attack or stroke regardless of how many kilograms people lose, the largest study of its kind has found.However, shrinking waist size – a sign of less belly fat – was linked to better heart outcomes, according to the research. Continue reading...
items.content: Semaglutide study suggests such drugs could have wider benefits, though researchers find shrinking waistlines linked to better heart outcomesThe weight-loss drug semaglutide cuts the risk of heart attack or stroke regardless of how many kilograms people lose, the largest study of its kind has found.However, shrinking waist size – a sign of less belly fat – was linked to better heart outcomes, according to the research. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Man murdered stranger in Devon park after losing mental health support, inquest hears
clusters.neutral_headline: Man Murdered After Losing Mental Health Support

items.title: Man murdered stranger in Devon park after losing mental health support, inquest hears
items.standfirst: Coroner said a care coordinator might have prompted a multi-agency risk meeting before Cameron Davis killed Lorna England, 74A man with mental health issues and a history of making violent threats murdered a woman in a Devon park after falling off a waiting list for a care coordinator, possibly because a health trust’s computer records were compromised by a cyber-attack, an inquest has heard.If Cameron Davis had been allocated a care coordinator, a multi-agency meeting on him may have been called before he stabbed Lorna England, 74, the senior coroner for Devon, Plymouth and Torbay, Philip Spinney, concluded. Continue reading...
items.content: Coroner said a care coordinator might have prompted a multi-agency risk meeting before Cameron Davis killed Lorna England, 74A man with mental health issues and a history of making violent threats murdered a woman in a Devon park after falling off a waiting list for a care coordinator, possibly because a health trust’s computer records were compromised by a cyber-attack, an inquest has heard.If Cameron Davis had been allocated a care coordinator, a multi-agency meeting on him may have been called before he stabbed Lorna England, 74, the senior coroner for Devon, Plymouth and Torbay, Philip Spinney, concluded. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A man murdered a woman after losing mental health support.
The victim was murdered in a Devon park.
The man had a history of violent threats.
A care coordinator might have prevented the murder.
A cyber-attack may have compromised health trust records.

clusters.title: Antidepressants differ in side-effects such as weight gain, UK research finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Antidepressants Have Varying Side Effects

items.title: Antidepressants differ in side-effects such as weight gain, UK research finds
items.standfirst: Notable variations between different medications were found in weight gain or loss, heart rate and blood pressurePeople taking certain types of antidepressants can gain up to 2kg (4.5lbs) in weight within the first two months of treatment, while patients taking other drugs can lose the equivalent or more, according to a major review of potential side-effects.The research, led by academics at King’s College London and the University of Oxford, found that while some antidepressants can cause notable changes in body weight, heart rate and blood pressure, others do not cause such physical changes. Continue reading...
items.content: Notable variations between different medications were found in weight gain or loss, heart rate and blood pressurePeople taking certain types of antidepressants can gain up to 2kg (4.5lbs) in weight within the first two months of treatment, while patients taking other drugs can lose the equivalent or more, according to a major review of potential side-effects.The research, led by academics at King’s College London and the University of Oxford, found that while some antidepressants can cause notable changes in body weight, heart rate and blood pressure, others do not cause such physical changes. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Antidepressants differ in side effects, including weight changes.
Some antidepressants can cause weight gain within two months.
Other antidepressants may lead to weight loss.
The research was led by King's College London and Oxford.
Variations were found in weight, heart rate, and blood pressure.

clusters.title: NHS staff: have you seen or been affected by violence in hospital?
clusters.neutral_headline: NHS Staff Asked About Violence in Hospitals

items.title: NHS staff: have you seen or been affected by violence in hospital?
items.standfirst: We’d like to hear people’s experiences of incidents of violence while working in NHS hospitalsAccording to the Royal College of Nursing, incidents of violence against A&E nurses have almost doubled over the last six years, often due to people being frustrated at waiting so long for care. Incidents include nurses being punched, spat at and pinned up against a wall.We would like to hear from NHS staff about their experiences of seeing or being the victim of violence in hospitals. What happened and was the incident reported? If the police were involved, what was the outcome? Continue reading...
items.content: We’d like to hear people’s experiences of incidents of violence while working in NHS hospitalsAccording to the Royal College of Nursing, incidents of violence against A&E nurses have almost doubled over the last six years, often due to people being frustrated at waiting so long for care. Incidents include nurses being punched, spat at and pinned up against a wall.We would like to hear from NHS staff about their experiences of seeing or being the victim of violence in hospitals. What happened and was the incident reported? If the police were involved, what was the outcome? Continue reading...

ai_summary: The Royal College of Nursing reports violence against A&E nurses.
Incidents of violence have almost doubled in six years.
The incidents often stem from frustration over waiting times.
The article seeks experiences of violence from NHS staff.
The goal is to gather information on violence in hospitals.

clusters.title: No prosecutions made after 15,195 wood-burning complaints in a year in England
clusters.neutral_headline: No Prosecutions After Wood-Burning Complaints in England

items.title: No prosecutions made after 15,195 wood-burning complaints in a year in England
items.standfirst: Campaigners say figures reveal a lack of enforcement with just 24 fines issued by councils for rule violationsNot one prosecution for illegal wood burning has been made in the past year, despite 15,195 complaints across England, data shows.Additionally, just 24 fines were issued by local authorities between September 2024 and August 2025, responses to freedom of information requests by the campaign group Mums for Lungs revealed.This article was amended on 22 October 2025. The original version stated that there had been just one prosecution in the last year; in fact there have been none. Continue reading...
items.content: Campaigners say figures reveal a lack of enforcement with just 24 fines issued by councils for rule violationsNot one prosecution for illegal wood burning has been made in the past year, despite 15,195 complaints across England, data shows.Additionally, just 24 fines were issued by local authorities between September 2024 and August 2025, responses to freedom of information requests by the campaign group Mums for Lungs revealed.This article was amended on 22 October 2025. The original version stated that there had been just one prosecution in the last year; in fact there have been none. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Over 15,000 wood-burning complaints were filed in England within a year.
No prosecutions were made despite the high number of complaints received.
Only 24 fines were issued by local authorities for wood-burning violations.
Data comes from freedom of information requests by the campaign group Mums for Lungs.
The original article was amended to correct the number of prosecutions.
